en_question: There has been an oil spill in the ocean and ducks must be transported to shore for cleaning. Rescuers can use three types of vessels: Boats carry 10 ducks per trip and take 20 minutes per trip; Canoes carry 8 ducks per trip and take 40 minutes per trip; Hovercraft carry 25 ducks per trip and take 35 minutes per trip. At least 300 ducks must be transported in total. To ensure safer operations, at least forty percent of all trips must be made by canoe. Staffing is limited: each boat trip and each canoe trip consumes one-half crew-hour, each hovercraft trip consumes one and one-half crew-hours, and the combined crew-hours across all trips cannot exceed eighteen. Operational limits also cap hovercraft usage at no more than five trips. Determine the integer number of trips by boats, canoes, and hovercraft that minimizes the total time spent transporting ducks. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

There has been an oil spill in the ocean and ducks must be transported to shore for cleaning. Boats carry 10 ducks per trip and take 20 minutes per trip, while canoes carry 8 ducks per trip and take 40 minutes per trip. At least 300 ducks must be rescued. To limit motor use, at least 70% of all trips must be made by canoe, and there can be at most 12 boat trips. Determine the number of boat and canoe trips that minimize the total transportation time. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

After an oil spill, rescuers use three types of vessels: Boats carry 10 ducks per trip and take 20 minutes; Canoes carry 8 ducks per trip and take 40 minutes; Hovercraft carry 25 ducks per trip and take 35 minutes. At least 400 ducks must be taken to shore. Canoe trips must make up at least 30% of all trips. No more than 5 hovercraft trips are allowed. Determine the integer number of each trip type to minimize total time. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

Ducks covered in oil are being transported to shore using Boats, Canoes, and Hovercraft. Boats take 20 minutes and use 0.5 crew-hours per trip; Canoes take 40 minutes and use 0.5 crew-hours; Hovercraft take 35 minutes and use 1.5 crew-hours. Boats carry 10 ducks, Canoes 8, and Hovercraft 25. At least 300 ducks must be moved, total crew-hours cannot exceed 18, and Hovercraft trips are capped at 5. Canoe trips must be at least 40% of all trips. Find integer trip counts that minimize total transport time. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

Ducks must be sent to two cleaning stations, A and B. Boats carry 10 ducks and take 22 minutes to A or 18 minutes to B. Canoes carry 8 ducks and take 45 minutes to A or 35 minutes to B. At least 200 ducks must go to A and 250 to B. Boats can make at most 15 total trips, and at least 40% of all trips must go to A. Determine integer trip counts to minimize total transportation time. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

A rescue team transports ducks using Boats and Canoes. Boats carry 10 ducks and take 20 minutes per trip in calm weather, but due to rain, each trip now takes 25 minutes. Canoes carry 8 ducks per trip, taking 40 minutes regardless of weather. At least 280 ducks must be transported. Boats can make at most 10 trips, and at least 50% of all trips must be by canoe. Determine the number of each trip type minimizing total time. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

After a major oil spill, rescuers use Boats, Canoes, and Hovercraft to clean ducks. Boats take 20 minutes, Canoes 40 minutes, Hovercraft 35 minutes. Each Boat and Canoe uses 0.5 crew-hours per trip, Hovercraft 1.5 crew-hours. Boats carry 10 ducks, Canoes 8, and Hovercraft 25. At least 450 ducks must be transported, total crew-hours cannot exceed 30, and no more than 8 Hovercraft trips are allowed. Canoe trips must be at least 35% of all trips. Determine the integer trip counts that minimize total transport time. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

Seabirds affected by an oil spill are transported to a rescue station using Boats, Canoes, and Hovercraft. Boats take 20 minutes and carry 10 birds per trip; Canoes take 40 minutes and carry 8; Hovercraft take 35 minutes and carry 25. At least 320 birds must be rescued. Canoe trips must account for at least 40% of all trips, Hovercraft trips are capped at 5, and total crew-hours (0.5 for Boat/Canoe, 1.5 for Hovercraft) cannot exceed 18. Determine the integer number of each vessel’s trips that minimize total time. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

To reduce emissions, a rescue operation limits total fuel use while transporting ducks. Boats use 3 fuel units per trip, Canoes use 0, and Hovercraft use 6. Boats carry 10 ducks per trip and take 20 minutes, Canoes carry 8 ducks and take 40 minutes, Hovercraft carry 25 ducks and take 35 minutes. At least 300 ducks must be moved, Canoes must make up at least 40% of all trips, Hovercraft trips are capped at 5, and total fuel use cannot exceed 80 units. Find the integer trips that minimize total time. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

A rescue operation spans two days. On each day, Boats and Canoes can operate for at most 12 hours. Boats take 20 minutes per trip and carry 10 ducks; Canoes take 40 minutes per trip and carry 8 ducks. At least 300 ducks must be transported in total. At least 60% of all trips must be by canoe. Determine how many boat and canoe trips per day should be scheduled to minimize total time without exceeding the daily operation limit. Return the optimal total time in minutes.

A patient in the hospital can take two pills, Pill 1 and Pill 2. Per pill, pill 1 provides 0.2 units of pain medication and 0.3 units of anxiety medication. Per pill, pill 2 provides 0.6 units of pain medication and 0.2 units of anxiety medication. In addition, pill 1 causes 0.3 units of discharge while pill 2 causes 0.1 units of discharge. At most 6 units of pain medication can be provided and at least 3 units of anxiety medication must be provided. How many pills of each should the patient be given to minimize the total amount of discharge?

A patient can take three pills: Pill 1, Pill 2, and Pill 3. Per pill, Pill 1 provides 0.2 units of pain relief and 0.3 units of anxiety relief, Pill 2 provides 0.6 units of pain relief and 0.2 units of anxiety relief, and Pill 3 provides 0.4 units of pain relief and 0.5 units of anxiety relief. The discharges caused are 0.3, 0.1, and 0.2 units respectively. The patient can receive at most 6 units of pain relief and must receive at least 3 units of anxiety relief. Determine how many pills of each should be given to minimize total discharge.

A patient can take two pills, Pill 1 and Pill 2. Pill 1 provides 0.2 pain relief and 0.3 anxiety relief per pill, while Pill 2 provides 0.6 pain relief and 0.2 anxiety relief per pill. Each pill also causes nausea (0.1 and 0.05 units respectively) and discharge (0.3 and 0.1 units respectively). The total nausea cannot exceed 1.0 units, the total pain relief cannot exceed 6 units, and anxiety relief must be at least 3 units. Minimize total discharge.

A doctor prescribes Pill 1 and Pill 2. Pill 1 provides 0.2 pain and 0.3 anxiety relief per pill, while Pill 2 provides 0.6 pain and 0.2 anxiety relief per pill. Each causes 0.3 and 0.1 units of discharge respectively. The patient must receive at least 3 units of anxiety relief and no more than 6 units of pain relief, with a total of at most 12 pills combined. Find the number of each pill minimizing total discharge.

A treatment involves Pill 1 and Pill 2. Pill 1 provides 0.2 pain and 0.3 anxiety relief; Pill 2 provides 0.6 pain and 0.2 anxiety relief. Discharges are 0.3 and 0.1 units respectively. To maintain stability, Pill 1 must account for at least 30% of all pills taken. The patient must receive at least 3 units of anxiety relief and not exceed 6 units of pain relief. Determine the number of each pill that minimizes total discharge.

A patient can take Pill 1 and Pill 2. Each Pill 1 provides 0.2 pain relief, 0.3 anxiety relief, and 0.1 vitamin dose. Each Pill 2 provides 0.6 pain relief, 0.2 anxiety relief, and 0.3 vitamin dose. Discharges are 0.3 and 0.1 units per pill respectively. The total vitamin intake cannot exceed 2.4 units, pain relief cannot exceed 6 units, and anxiety relief must be at least 3 units. Minimize total discharge.

A treatment uses two pills: Pill 1 provides 0.2 pain relief, 0.3 anxiety relief, and 0.4 sleep improvement per pill. Pill 2 provides 0.6 pain relief, 0.2 anxiety relief, and 0.1 sleep improvement. Discharges are 0.3 and 0.1 respectively. The patient must have at least 3 units of anxiety relief and 2 units of sleep improvement, while pain relief must not exceed 6 units. Minimize total discharge.

A doctor chooses between Pill 1 and Pill 2. Each Pill 1 gives 0.2 pain relief, 0.3 anxiety relief, and costs $1 with 0.3 discharge. Each Pill 2 gives 0.6 pain relief, 0.2 anxiety relief, and costs $2 with 0.1 discharge. The patient needs at least 3 anxiety units and no more than 6 pain units. The doctor minimizes total (discharge + 0.1 × cost). Determine how many of each pill to give.

Two pills are available. Pill 1 provides 0.2 pain and 0.3 anxiety relief per pill and causes 0.3 discharge and 0.2 drowsiness. Pill 2 provides 0.6 pain and 0.2 anxiety relief per pill and causes 0.1 discharge and 0.4 drowsiness. The total drowsiness cannot exceed 2.5 units, pain relief cannot exceed 6 units, and anxiety relief must be at least 3 units. Minimize total discharge.

A hospital must prepare dosages for two patients using Pill 1 and Pill 2. Both pills have the same properties: Pill 1 provides 0.2 pain and 0.3 anxiety relief per pill with 0.3 discharge; Pill 2 provides 0.6 pain and 0.2 anxiety relief with 0.1 discharge. Across both patients combined, at least 6 units of anxiety relief are required and total pain relief cannot exceed 12 units. Determine the total number of each pill minimizing total discharge.

There is 1000 mg of gold available that is needed to make long and short cables. Long cables require 10 mg of gold while short cables require 7 mg of gold. Because of their compact size, at least 5 times the number of short cables are needed than the long cables. In addition, there needs to be at least 10 long cables made. If each long cable sold results in a $12 profit and each short cable sold results in a $5 profit, how many of each type of cable should be made to maximize profit?

A factory has 1000 mg of gold available to produce long, medium, and short cables. Each long cable requires 10 mg of gold, each medium cable 8 mg, and each short cable 7 mg. At least 5 times as many short cables must be made as long ones, and at least twice as many medium cables as long ones. A minimum of 10 long cables is required. Profits are $12, $8, and $5 per long, medium, and short cable respectively. Determine how many of each cable should be made to maximize profit.

There is 1000 mg of gold and 600 mg of silver available to make long and short cables. Long cables require 10 mg of gold and 8 mg of silver, while short cables require 7 mg of gold and 3 mg of silver. At least 5 times as many short cables as long cables must be produced, and at least 10 long cables are required. Each long cable earns $12 profit and each short cable $5. Maximize profit under both metal limits.

A plant uses 1000 mg of gold to make long and short cables. Long cables require 10 mg each, short cables 7 mg each. At least 5 times as many short cables as long cables must be made, and at least 10 long cables are required. However, storage can hold at most 160 total cables. Each long cable earns $12 profit and each short cable $5. Find the quantities that maximize profit.

A manufacturer can produce long and short gold cables using 1000 mg of gold and 200 mg of copper. Long cables use 10 mg of gold and 3 mg of copper, short cables use 7 mg of gold and 2 mg of copper. At least 5 times as many short cables as long cables must be produced, and at least 10 long cables are needed. Each long cable yields $12 profit, each short cable $5. Maximize profit.

A workshop produces long and short cables with 1000 mg of gold. Long cables need 10 mg of gold and 0.5 labor hours each, short cables need 7 mg of gold and 0.2 labor hours each. Total labor hours cannot exceed 40. At least 5 times as many short cables as long cables must be made, and at least 10 long cables are required. Each long cable earns $12, each short cable $5. Maximize total profit.

Using 1000 mg of gold, a factory produces long and short cables. Long cables use 10 mg of gold and short cables 7 mg. At least 5 times as many short cables as long cables must be made, and at least 10 long cables are required. However, due to market demand, no more than 250 short cables can be sold. Each long cable earns $12 profit, each short cable $5. Maximize profit.

A manufacturer has 1000 mg of gold and 400 mg of platinum to make long and short cables. Long cables require 10 mg of gold and 2 mg of platinum, while short cables require 7 mg of gold and 1 mg of platinum. At least 5 times as many short cables as long cables must be produced, and at least 10 long cables are required. Profits are $12 per long and $5 per short cable. Maximize total profit.

A company makes long and short cables using 1000 mg of gold. Long cables require 10 mg and short cables 7 mg each. At least 5 times as many short cables as long ones must be made, and at least 10 long cables are needed. Premium versions of each cable can be made, earning $15 for premium long and $7 for premium short, but only up to 20% of cables can be premium. Determine how many of each to make to maximize profit.

A plant has 1000 mg of gold to make long and short cables. Each long cable uses 10 mg, each short 7 mg. At least 5 times as many short cables as long cables must be made, and at least 10 long cables are required. Each cable recovers 10% of its gold after sale (recyclable). The effective gold used must stay within 1000 mg, and profits are $12 and $5 for long and short cables respectively. Maximize profit.

A suspicious factory has 100 sq. feet of space. It makes bootleg phones and laptops. Phones require 2 hours of labor and cost $12 for each sq. foot of space allocated for phone production (cost of electricity and equipment). Laptops require 3 hours of labor and cost $15 for each sq. foot of space allocated for laptop production. Phones produce a net revenue of $50 per sq. foot while laptops produce a net revenue of $70 per sq. foot. The factory wants to spend at most $5000 and 2000 hours of labor. What is the optimal factory layout to maximize revenue?

A factory has 100 sq. feet of space to produce bootleg phones, tablets, and laptops. Phones require 2 hours of labor and cost $12 per sq. foot, tablets require 2.5 hours and cost $13 per sq. foot, and laptops require 3 hours and cost $15 per sq. foot. Each sq. foot of phones, tablets, and laptops yields revenues of $50, $60, and $70 respectively. The factory can spend at most $5000 and 2000 hours of labor. Determine the optimal allocation to maximize revenue.

A small factory has 100 sq. feet of space to make bootleg phones and laptops. Phones need 2 labor hours and cost $12 per sq. foot, laptops need 3 hours and cost $15 per sq. foot. Each sq. foot of phone production yields $50 and each sq. foot of laptop production yields $70 in revenue. The factory can spend at most $5000 and 2000 hours of labor but must dedicate at least 20 sq. feet to phone production due to existing contracts. Determine the optimal layout to maximize revenue.

A factory produces phones and laptops using 100 sq. feet of space. Phones use 2 labor hours, cost $12 per sq. foot, and consume 8 electricity units. Laptops use 3 labor hours, cost $15 per sq. foot, and consume 12 electricity units. At most 800 electricity units and $5000 can be spent, and total labor cannot exceed 2000 hours. Phones earn $50 per sq. foot and laptops $70. Determine the optimal production layout to maximize revenue.

A 100 sq. foot factory makes bootleg phones and laptops. Phones require 1 hour of skilled and 1 hour of unskilled labor, while laptops require 2 hours of skilled and 1 hour of unskilled labor. Skilled labor is limited to 1200 hours, unskilled to 1000 hours. Phones cost $12 per sq. foot, laptops $15, and total spending cannot exceed $5000. Phones earn $50 per sq. foot, laptops $70. Maximize total revenue.

A factory produces bootleg phones and laptops in 100 sq. feet. Phones require 2 labor hours, cost $12 per sq. foot, and earn $50 per sq. foot. Laptops require 3 labor hours, cost $15 per sq. foot, and earn $70 per sq. foot. Total labor cannot exceed 2000 hours and spending cannot exceed $5000. Due to market balance, the area for laptops must not exceed twice the area for phones. Find the optimal layout to maximize revenue.

A bootleg factory with 100 sq. feet of space makes phones and laptops. Phones use 2 labor hours and cost $12 per sq. foot, laptops use 3 labor hours and cost $15 per sq. foot. Each sq. foot of phones and laptops yields $50 and $70 revenue respectively. The factory has at most 2000 labor hours and $5000 budget. Every 10 sq. feet of production requires 1 maintenance hour, and total maintenance hours must not exceed 9. Determine the layout maximizing revenue.

A factory produces phones and laptops with 100 sq. feet of space. Phones require 4 kg of aluminum and 1 kg of silicon per sq. foot, while laptops require 3 kg of aluminum and 2 kg of silicon. Available resources are 350 kg aluminum and 120 kg silicon. Each sq. foot of phone and laptop space costs $12 and $15 respectively, and total cost cannot exceed $5000. Labor is limited to 2000 hours (2 hours per phone, 3 per laptop). Phones yield $50 per sq. foot, laptops $70. Maximize total revenue.

A 100 sq. foot factory makes phones and laptops in regular and premium versions. Regular phones yield $50 per sq. foot, premium phones $65. Regular laptops yield $70 per sq. foot, premium laptops $90. Premium products cost $18 per sq. foot more than regular ones. Labor is 2 hours for phones and 3 hours for laptops. The factory can spend at most $7000 and 2000 hours of labor. At most 30% of production can be premium. Determine the layout that maximizes revenue.

A 100 sq. foot factory produces bootleg phones and laptops. Phones require 2 labor hours, cost $12 per sq. foot, and emit 3 CO₂ units. Laptops require 3 labor hours, cost $15 per sq. foot, and emit 5 CO₂ units. The factory can emit at most 350 CO₂ units, use 2000 labor hours, and spend up to $5000. Each sq. foot of phones yields $50 and each sq. foot of laptops yields $70 in revenue. Determine the layout that maximizes total revenue.

An accounting firm has senior accountants earning $3000 per week and junior accountants earning $1000 per week. The contracts with companies to provide accounting services require at least 100 accountants, of whom at least 5 must be senior accountants. To make sure there is enough experience on the accounting team, the number of senior accountants should be at least a third of the number to junior accountants. The firm wants to keep the weekly wage bill below $150000. Formulate an LP to minimize the wage bill.

An accounting firm hires senior and junior accountants. Seniors cost $3000/week; juniors cost $1000/week. At least 120 accountants are required in total, with at least 8 seniors. To ensure experience balance, the number of seniors must be at least half the number of juniors (i.e., juniors ≤ 2 × seniors). Formulate an LP to minimize the weekly wage bill and determine the optimal staffing.

A firm hires seniors ($3000/week) and juniors ($1000/week). At least 140 total accountants are required, with at least 30 seniors. For experience, seniors must be at least a third of juniors (equivalently juniors ≤ 3 × seniors). Minimize the wage bill and give the optimal staffing.

Due to regional premiums, seniors cost $3200/week and juniors $900/week. The firm needs at least 180 accountants in total and at least 20 seniors. To maintain experience, seniors must be at least a third of juniors (juniors ≤ 3 × seniors). Minimize the weekly wage bill and provide the optimal staffing.

The firm can hire seniors ($3000/week), mid-levels ($2000/week), and juniors ($1000/week). At least 150 accountants are required in total. At least 10 mid-levels are required to mentor juniors. For experience balance, juniors may not exceed 4 times the number of seniors (juniors ≤ 4 × seniors). Minimize the weekly wage bill and determine the optimal staffing.

Seniors cost $3000/week and juniors $1000/week. The firm needs at least 160 accountants total and at least 30 seniors. Experience requires seniors to be at least a third of juniors (juniors ≤ 3 × seniors). Due to market constraints, at most 90 juniors can be hired. Minimize the weekly wage bill and report the optimal staffing.

The firm may hire seniors ($3000/week), juniors ($1000/week), and interns ($600/week). At least 180 total staff are required, with experience rule juniors ≤ 4 × seniors and a supervision rule interns ≤ seniors. Minimize the weekly wage bill and provide the optimal staffing.

In a different city, seniors cost $2800/week and juniors $1200/week. At least 150 total accountants are needed. For experience balance, seniors must be at least half of juniors (juniors ≤ 2 × seniors). Minimize the weekly wage bill and give the optimal staffing.

A firm pays seniors $3000/week and juniors $1000/week plus a flat overhead of $200 per hire for benefits. Thus effective weekly costs are $3200 for seniors and $1200 for juniors. At least 200 total accountants are required, with seniors at least a third of juniors (juniors ≤ 3 × seniors). Minimize the weekly wage bill and report the optimal staffing.

Seniors earn $3000/week and juniors $1000/week. The firm requires at least 220 accountants, with seniors at least a third of juniors (juniors ≤ 3 × seniors). However, due to availability, at most 60 seniors can be hired. Minimize the wage bill and provide the optimal staffing.

An extremely large ski resort is looking into purchasing two types of ski lifts, a densely-seated one and a loosely-seated one. The densely-seated ski lift is able to bring 45 guests up the slopes every minute whereas the loosely-seated ski lift can transport 20 guests every minute.  The densely-seated ski lift uses 30 units of electricity and the loosely-seated lift uses 22 units of electricity. There must be at least five loosely-seated ski lifts because they move slower and are friendlier for beginners. The ski resort needs at least 1000 guests every minute to make a profit and has available 940 units of electricity. How many of each type of ski lifts should they plan to install to minimize the total number of ski lifts needed?

A ski resort can install three types of ski lifts: densely-seated, loosely-seated, and high-speed lifts. Densely-seated lifts carry 45 guests per minute using 30 electricity units; loosely-seated lifts carry 20 guests per minute using 22 electricity units; high-speed lifts carry 70 guests per minute using 45 electricity units. At least five loosely-seated lifts are required for beginners, and at least two high-speed lifts are needed to meet peak demand. The resort must transport at least 1500 guests per minute with 1500 electricity units available. Determine the number of each lift to minimize the total number of lifts.

The ski resort installs densely- and loosely-seated lifts. Densely-seated lifts carry 45 guests per minute using 30 electricity units and require 3 maintenance hours weekly; loosely-seated lifts carry 20 guests per minute using 22 electricity units and require 2 maintenance hours weekly. Maintenance resources allow for at most 80 hours per week. At least 5 loosely-seated lifts are required, 1000 guests per minute must be carried, and 940 electricity units are available. Minimize the total number of lifts.

The ski resort has limited beginner terrain, allowing a maximum of 10 loosely-seated lifts. Each densely-seated lift carries 45 guests per minute and uses 30 electricity units; each loosely-seated lift carries 20 guests and uses 22 units. At least 5 loosely-seated lifts are required, the resort must carry at least 1000 guests per minute, and total electricity cannot exceed 940 units. Determine the lift configuration that minimizes the total number of lifts.

Densely-seated ski lifts carry 45 guests/min using 30 electricity units; loosely-seated lifts carry 20 guests/min using 22 units. Each electricity unit produces 0.2 kg of CO₂. The resort must transport at least 1200 guests per minute, keep emissions below 200 kg of CO₂, and have at least five loosely-seated lifts. Minimize the total number of lifts.

The ski resort operates two zones: advanced and beginner. In the advanced zone, only densely-seated lifts can be used; in the beginner zone, only loosely-seated lifts are allowed. Each dense lift carries 45 guests/min using 30 electricity units, and each loose lift carries 20 guests/min using 22 units. The advanced zone must move at least 700 guests/min and the beginner zone at least 300 guests/min. Total electricity cannot exceed 940 units. Minimize the total number of lifts.

The ski resort installs two types of lifts. Densely-seated lifts transport 45 guests/min using 30 electricity units; loosely-seated lifts transport 20 guests/min using 22 electricity units. At least five loosely-seated lifts are needed for beginners and at least three densely-seated lifts for advanced riders. The resort must move at least 1000 guests per minute under a 940-unit electricity limit. Minimize the total lifts required.

A ski resort installs densely-seated ($400,000 each, 45 guests/min, 30 electricity units) and loosely-seated ($250,000 each, 20 guests/min, 22 electricity units) lifts. The resort must carry at least 1400 guests/min, stay under 1300 electricity units, and have at least 5 loosely-seated lifts. To encourage efficiency, each dense lift counts twice as heavily toward a maintenance penalty score. Minimize the total penalty score (number of dense lifts ×2 + loose lifts).

Each densely-seated ski lift can run up to 12 hours per day while each loosely-seated lift can run up to 14 hours. They transport 45 and 20 guests per minute respectively, using 30 and 22 electricity units. The resort must move at least 1000 guests per minute on average over 12 hours of operation and has 940 electricity units available. At least five loosely-seated lifts are required. Minimize the total number of lifts installed.

A ski resort installs three types of lifts: densely-seated (45 guests/min, 30 electricity units, $400k each), loosely-seated (20 guests/min, 22 electricity units, $250k each), and luxury gondolas (80 guests/min, 50 electricity units, $600k each). At least five loosely-seated lifts are required, at least one luxury gondola must be built, total electricity cannot exceed 1500 units, and total cost cannot exceed $14.2 million. The resort must transport at least 1800 guests per minute. Minimize the total number of lifts.

A woman has $100000 to gamble on two sports bets: a basketball tournament, a horse race, and a soccer game. Based on simple analysis, the woman determines her chance of losing her money would be 50% for basketball tournament, 25% for horse race, and 10% for the soccer game. The payout for each dollar put on each bet will be $1.2 for basketball tournament, $0.5 for horse race, and $0.1 for the soccer game. Knowing herself, she limits her average chance of losing her money should be at most 30%. Could you help her determine how much to money to put on each sport bet to maximize her average payout?

A woman has $100000 to split across four sports bets: a basketball tournament, a horse race, a soccer game, and a tennis major. Estimated loss chances are 50% (basketball), 25% (horse), 10% (soccer), and 15% (tennis). Payout per $1 wagered: $1.2 (basketball), $0.5 (horse), $0.1 (soccer), $0.6 (tennis). She requires the weighted-average loss chance to be at most 30%. How much should she put on each bet to maximize average payout?

A cautious bettor has $100,000 to wager on basketball, horse racing, soccer, and tennis. The chance of losing money is 50%, 25%, 10%, and 15% respectively. Payouts per dollar are $1.2, $0.5, $0.1, and $0.6 respectively. She wants to keep the weighted-average chance of losing below 25%. Determine how she should allocate her money to maximize the expected payout.

A woman wants to invest $100,000 in three sports bets: basketball, soccer, and tennis. Basketball has a 50% chance of losing and pays $1.2 per dollar, soccer has a 10% loss chance and pays $0.1 per dollar, and tennis has a 15% loss chance and pays $0.6 per dollar. To manage risk, she can place at most $30,000 on basketball, and the weighted-average chance of losing must not exceed 30%. How should she allocate her money to maximize payout?

A woman with $100,000 decides to only bet on basketball and soccer. Basketball carries a 50% chance of loss and pays $1.2 per dollar, while soccer carries a 10% loss chance and pays $0.2 per dollar. She wants to ensure that at least 20% of her total bets go to soccer and that her overall chance of losing does not exceed 32%. Find the optimal allocation to maximize her total payout.

A bettor splits $100,000 across basketball, horse racing, soccer, and tennis. The loss probabilities are 50%, 25%, 10%, and 15%, and the payouts per dollar are $1.2, $0.5, $0.1, and $0.6 respectively. She requires that the weighted-average loss probability remain at or below 27%. Determine how she should allocate her funds to maximize her total expected payout.

A woman can bet $100,000 on basketball, soccer, and tennis. Basketball has a 50% chance of losing and pays $1.2 per dollar, soccer has a 10% chance of losing and pays $0.2, and tennis has a 15% chance of losing and pays $0.6. The weighted-average loss chance must not exceed 30%, and she cannot spend more than 50% of her budget on tennis. How should she allocate her funds to maximize payout?

A woman wants to bet $100,000 across basketball, horse racing, and soccer. Basketball has a 50% chance of loss and pays $1.2 per dollar, horse racing has a 25% chance of loss and pays $0.5, and soccer has a 10% chance of loss and pays $0.1. She must invest at least 20% of her budget in horse racing, and the overall chance of losing money must be 30% or less. How should she invest to maximize her expected payout?

A high-stakes bettor has $200,000 to divide between basketball and tennis bets. The basketball bet has a 50% loss probability and pays $1.2 per dollar, while tennis has a 15% loss probability and pays $0.6 per dollar. To limit exposure, the weighted-average loss chance must be at most 30%. Find the allocation that maximizes her expected total payout.

A woman has $100,000 to bet on basketball, tennis, and soccer. Basketball has a 50% chance of losing and pays $1.2 per dollar, tennis has a 15% loss chance and pays $0.6, and soccer has a 10% loss chance and pays $0.2. She will invest no more than 30% of her total in basketball, and her weighted-average loss probability must be 30% or less. How should she allocate her bets to maximize payout?

A new fast food place makes wraps and platters. Each wrap requires 5 units of meat and 3 units of rice. Each platter requires 7 units of meant and 5 units of rice. While each wrap takes 10 minutes to make, each platter takes 8 minutes to make. The fast food place must use at least 3000 units of meat and 2500 units of rice. Since wraps are easier to eat on the go, at least 3 times as many wraps need to be made as platter. How many of each should the fast food place make to minimize the total production time?

A new fast food restaurant makes wraps, platters, and salads. Each wrap requires 5 units of meat and 3 units of rice, each platter requires 7 units of meat and 5 units of rice, and each salad requires 2 units of meat and 6 units of rice. Wraps take 10 minutes to prepare, platters take 8 minutes, and salads take 5 minutes. The restaurant must use at least 3000 units of meat and 2500 units of rice. Additionally, there must be at least twice as many wraps as platters and at least 200 salads to offer healthier options. How many of each should be made to minimize the total preparation time?

A fast food place makes wraps and platters. Wraps need 5 units of meat, 3 of rice, and 10 minutes of labor. Platters need 7 units of meat, 5 of rice, and 8 minutes of labor. The restaurant has at most 10,000 minutes of total labor available, must use at least 3000 units of meat and 2500 units of rice, and make at least three times as many wraps as platters. How many of each should be made to minimize total production time?

A restaurant makes wraps and platters. Each wrap uses 5 units of meat ($2 per unit) and 3 units of rice ($1 per unit). Each platter uses 7 units of meat ($2 per unit) and 5 units of rice ($1 per unit). Wraps take 10 minutes to make and platters 8 minutes. The restaurant can spend at most $10,500 on ingredients, must use at least 3000 units of meat and 2500 units of rice, and must make at least three times as many wraps as platters. Find the production plan that minimizes total time.

A fast food restaurant produces wraps and platters. Each wrap needs 5 units of meat and 3 of rice, and each platter needs 7 units of meat and 5 of rice. Wraps take 10 minutes to make and platters 8 minutes. The restaurant has at most 3000 units of rice available and must use at least 3000 units of meat. There must be at least three times as many wraps as platters. How many of each should be made to minimize total cooking time?

A fast food shop prepares wraps and platters. Wraps use 5 meat and 3 rice units, take 10 minutes, and earn $6 profit each. Platters use 7 meat and 5 rice units, take 8 minutes, and earn $9 profit each. The restaurant must use at least 3000 meat and 2500 rice units and must make at least three times as many wraps as platters. To maintain menu diversity, at least 200 platters must be produced. Find the number of each to minimize the total production time while satisfying these constraints.

A fast food place makes wraps and platters. Wraps use 5 units of meat and 3 of rice, while platters use 7 units of meat and 5 of rice. Wraps take 10 minutes to make, platters take 8. The kitchen can handle at most 900 servings total due to limited equipment. At least 3 times as many wraps as platters are required, and the restaurant must use at least 2500 rice and 3000 meat units. How many of each should be made to minimize total production time?

A fast food restaurant produces wraps and platters. Each wrap requires 5 units of meat, 3 of rice, and takes 10 minutes to make. Each platter requires 7 units of meat, 5 of rice, and takes 8 minutes to make. The restaurant must use at least 3000 units of meat and 2500 units of rice. Customer data shows that wraps must make up at least 80% of all items prepared. Determine how many of each should be made to minimize total production time.

A small fast food outlet makes wraps and platters. Each wrap needs 5 meat and 3 rice units and takes 10 minutes to make. Each platter uses 7 meat and 5 rice units and takes 8 minutes. The outlet can buy at most 4000 units of meat, must use at least 2500 units of rice, and should make at least three times as many wraps as platters. Find the optimal production plan to minimize total preparation time.

A fast food restaurant makes wraps and platters using meat, rice, and vegetables. Each wrap uses 5 units of meat, 3 of rice, and 4 of vegetables. Each platter uses 7 units of meat, 5 of rice, and 6 of vegetables. Wraps take 10 minutes to make and platters 8 minutes. The restaurant has at least 3000 meat, 2500 rice, and 3500 vegetable units. At least three times as many wraps must be produced as platters. Find the quantities that minimize the total cooking time.

Mrs. Watson wants to invest in the real-estate market and has a total budget of at most $760000. She has two choices which include condos and detached houses. Each dollar invested in condos yields a $0.50 profit and each dollar invested in detached houses yields a $1 profit. A minimum of 20% of all money invested must be in condos, and at least $20000 must be in detached houses. Formulate an LP that can be used to maximize total profit earned from Mrs. Watson's investment.

Mrs. Watson plans to invest at most $900,000 across three real-estate assets: condos, townhouses, and detached houses. Per dollar invested, expected profits are $0.50 for condos, $0.80 for townhouses, and $1.00 for detached houses. She must invest at least 25% of her total investment in condos and at least $100,000 in townhouses, and at least $200,000 must go to detached houses. Formulate an LP to maximize total profit and determine the optimal allocation.

Mrs. Watson has up to $760,000 to allocate between condos and detached houses. Condos yield $0.50 profit per dollar; detached houses yield $1.00 per dollar. For diversification, at least 20% of the total must be in condos and at least $20,000 in detached houses. A risk cap requires that 1.0 × (money in houses) + 0.3 × (money in condos) is at most 60% of the total budget. Maximize total profit and find the optimal investment.

Mrs. Watson may invest up to $800,000 in condos and detached houses. Condos earn $0.50 per dollar and detached houses earn $1.00 per dollar. At least 30% of the total must be invested in condos, and investment in detached houses cannot exceed $350,000 (but must be at least $50,000). Maximize total profit and report the optimal allocation.

Mrs. Watson can invest up to her $760,000 budget and may also borrow up to $200,000 at an interest cost that reduces profit by $0.10 per borrowed dollar. Condos yield $0.50 profit per invested dollar and detached houses yield $1.00. At least 20% of the total invested amount (including borrowed funds) must go to condos, and at least $20,000 must go to detached houses. Determine the investment and borrowing amounts that maximize total profit.

Mrs. Watson will invest across two cities (A and B) with a combined budget of at most $900,000. In each city, condos yield $0.50 profit per dollar and detached houses yield $1.00 per dollar. She must invest at least $300,000 in City A and at least $300,000 in City B. In each city, at least 20% of that city's investment must go to condos. Formulate an LP to maximize total profit and determine the optimal allocations across asset types and cities.

Mrs. Watson can invest up to $760,000 across condos, REITs, and detached houses. Expected profit per dollar is $0.50 for condos, $0.70 for REITs, and $1.00 for detached houses. A portfolio risk constraint limits 0.2 × (condo dollars) + 0.4 × (REIT dollars) + 1.0 × (house dollars) to at most 50% of the $760,000 budget. At least 20% of the total must be in condos and at least $100,000 must be in REITs. Maximize profit and give the optimal allocation.

Mrs. Watson invests up to $760,000 in condos and detached houses. Condo profits are taxed at 20%, so their effective profit is $0.40 per dollar; detached houses earn $1.00 per dollar with no tax. She must invest at least 25% of the total in condos and at least $50,000 in detached houses. Maximize total profit and determine the optimal allocation.

Mrs. Watson has a $1,000,000 budget to allocate between condos and detached houses. Condos yield $0.50 profit per dollar and houses yield $1.00 per dollar. Diversification constraints require that condos account for between 20% and 40% of the total budget and detached houses between 40% and 80%. Formulate an LP to maximize total profit and provide the optimal allocation.

Mrs. Watson has a $760,000 budget but must keep at least 10% in cash (uninvested). The remaining funds may be invested in condos (profit $0.50 per dollar) and detached houses (profit $1.00 per dollar). At least 20% of the invested amount must go to condos and at least $50,000 must go to detached houses. Maximize profit and state the optimal allocation and cash reserve.

Jordan is a chef. He wants to design a diet consisting of Kebabs and Rice.  Assume that each serving of Rice costs $3 and contains 300 calories and 4.5 grams of protein. Assume that each serving of Kebab costs $2 and contains 200 calories and 4 grams of protein. He's interested in spending as little money as possible but he wants to ensure that his meals have at least 2200 calories and at least 30 grams of protein per day. Formulate a linear programming problem that will help minimize the cost of the diet.

Jordan is a chef designing a daily diet that includes Kebabs, Rice, and Salad. Each serving of Rice costs $3, provides 300 calories and 4.5 g of protein. Each Kebab serving costs $2, provides 200 calories and 4 g of protein. Each Salad serving costs $1, provides 100 calories and 2 g of protein. He wants at least 2400 calories and 35 g of protein per day, while minimizing total cost. Determine the optimal number of servings of each food.

Jordan’s daily diet consists of Kebabs and Rice. Each Rice serving costs $3, gives 300 calories, 4.5 g protein, and 2 g fat. Each Kebab costs $2, gives 200 calories, 4 g protein, and 5 g fat. He wants at least 2200 calories and 30 g of protein, but total fat must not exceed 40 g. Find the optimal number of servings to minimize cost.

Jordan adds a vegetarian dish, Lentil Curry, to his meal plan. Each serving of Rice costs $3 (300 cal, 4.5 g protein), Kebabs cost $2 (200 cal, 4 g protein), and Lentil Curry costs $2.5 (250 cal, 6 g protein). He wants at least 2500 calories and 40 g of protein. To maintain variety, no more than half of the servings can be Kebabs. Formulate the LP to minimize cost.

Jordan wants a balanced plan using Kebabs and Rice. Each Kebab costs $2 and provides 200 calories and 4 g protein. Each Rice serving costs $3 and provides 300 calories and 4.5 g protein. He needs between 2200 and 2600 calories per day, at least 35 g of protein, and wants to minimize total cost.

Jordan includes Kebabs and Rice in his diet. Each Kebab costs $2, gives 200 calories, 4 g protein, and 0.5 g fiber. Each Rice serving costs $3, gives 300 calories, 4.5 g protein, and 1 g fiber. He wants at least 2200 calories, 30 g protein, and 6 g fiber daily, minimizing cost.

Jordan prepares meals using Kebabs and Rice. Each Kebab costs $2 (200 cal, 4 g protein), each Rice serving costs $3 (300 cal, 4.5 g protein). He wants at least 2200 calories and 30 g protein daily, but can serve at most 6 portions of Rice and 8 Kebabs per day. Find the minimum-cost combination.

Jordan plans his daily diet with Kebabs and Rice. Each Kebab costs $2 (200 cal, 4 g protein), and each Rice serving costs $3 (300 cal, 4.5 g protein). He needs at least 2200 calories and 30 g protein per day and wants at least 8 total servings of food to stay full. Minimize total cost.

Jordan has a $25 daily food budget. Kebabs cost $2 (200 cal, 4 g protein), and Rice costs $3 (300 cal, 4.5 g protein). He must consume at least 2400 calories and 35 g protein without exceeding his budget. Determine the diet combination that meets all requirements with minimum cost.

Jordan’s meal plan includes Kebabs and Rice. Kebabs cost $2 and provide 200 calories, 4 g protein. Rice costs $3 and provides 300 calories, 4.5 g protein. He needs at least 2200 calories, 30 g protein, and wants his protein-to-calorie ratio to be at least 1.2%. Find the least-cost plan.
